title: You’re probably wondering why I’ve called you here today
summary:
Key ideas:
- The blog is called Slate Star Codex and its ethos is charity over absurdity.
- Absurdity is the tendency to dismiss what you disagree with as too stupid to consider.
- Charity is the ability to override this tendency and try to understand why someone believes something.
- Charity is not the obligation to research every crazy belief, but it is advantageous even when it is uncalled-for.
- Steelmanning is the idea of rebuilding a stupid position into the nearest intelligent position and seeing what can be learned from it.
 
Key learnings:
- Charity is important in avoiding dismissing opposing views without understanding them.
- Time is valuable, so only wild goose chases should be avoided but sometimes a wrong position can teach valuable lessons through steelmanning.
 
Key questions:
- Who was Chesterton and why is his “fence” analogy important?
- What is steelmanning and how can it be used to learn from opposing views?
- How is charity different from a “fuzzy-headed caricature-pomo attempt to say no one can ever be sure they’re right or wrong about anything”?
